function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Technical and methodological differences between ground-stations and satellite observations could lead to discordance in correlation analyses, impacting the interpretation of air pollution levels.","Impact":"Misinterpretation of the role of specific air pollutants in relation to health issues such as COVID-19 infections.","Mitigation":"Harmonizing and validating the data from both sources to ensure accurate correlation analyses. Implement statistical adjustments to account for discrepancies.","Technologies":"Data validation and harmonization algorithms, statistical modeling for data adjustment.","People":"Data analysts, researchers, public health officials.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health organizations."},{"Description":"Uneven spatial coverage and limited spatial coverage of traditional ground stations may lead to incomplete representation of pollution levels experienced by populations in their proximity.","Impact":"Inaccurate assessment of pollution levels for populations living near traditional ground stations.","Mitigation":"Expand the spatial coverage of ground stations or supplement with additional monitoring tools. Utilize spatial interpolation techniques to estimate pollution levels in uncovered areas.","Technologies":"Air quality monitoring technologies, spatial interpolation algorithms.","People":"Environmental regulators, researchers, public health officials.","Owner":"Government agencies, research institutions."},{"Description":"Limited information about covariables such as health services, epidemiological traits, and population movement hinders the assessment of the relative importance of air pollution among socio-environmental driving factors of COVID-19 infections.","Impact":"Inability to ascertain the specific role of air pollution in relation to COVID-19 infections due to lack of comprehensive covariable data.","Mitigation":"Integrate high-resolution data regarding health services, epidemiological traits, and population movement to better understand the relative importance of air pollution. Conduct comprehensive studies to fill data gaps.","Technologies":"Data integration systems, high-resolution data collection tools, comprehensive epidemiological studies.","People":"Epidemiologists, public health researchers, data scientists.","Owner":"Public health organizations, research institutions."}]}
